 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into an ornamental art form and artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

 ===Architecture===
 {{Main|Ukrainian architecture}}
 [[File:Kyjiw stmichael.jpg|thumb|Golden-Domed Baroque architecture]]
+Ukrainian architecture reflects distinct features of that particular location and time period. Design and architecture are influenced by the existing political and economic climate.
 
 ====Vernacular architecture====
 Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations. The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]]. The open air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.

+Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations. The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]]. The open air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects. The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into an ornamental art form and artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

 '''Ukrainian culture''' and customs of [[Ukraine]] and ethnic [[Ukrainians]] contain a blend of [[Eastern European]] and [[Western European]] elements. Ukraine has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, dating back to the 9th century and the [[Rus (name)|Land of Rus]]. Mutual customs are shared among the cultures of [[Russian culture|Russia]], [[Ukraine]], [[Culture of Poland|Poland]], [[Culture of Belarus|Belarus]], [[Ukrainian Cossacks]] and [[Turkic peoples]] of [[Central Asia]]. Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language.

 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

 Ukraine greatly benefitted from the Soviet emphasis on [[physical education]], which left Ukraine with hundreds of stadiums, swimming pools, gymnasiums, and many other athletic facilities.
 
 [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]]. The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].

 ===Performance art===
 ====Dance====
 {{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
-[[Image:Гопак.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
+[[Image:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].

@@ -45,6 +45,7 @@
 Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations. The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]]. The open air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects. The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
+[[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. 
 
 ====Jewelry====

 ====Traditional costume====
-For men, traditional dress includes [[Kozhukh]], [[Kontusz]], [[Żupan]] and [[Sharovary]]. +For men, traditional dress includes [[Kozhukh]], [[Kontusz]], [[Żupan]] and [[Sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[Vyshyvanka]], [[Kozhushanka]], [[Ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes |title=Travel to Ukraine. Ukraine country guide, information about Ukraine. Visit Ukraine, places, tourism, tours |publisher=Ua-travelling.com |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}{{dead link|date=December 2010}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].

 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a wiling participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. +Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a wiling participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.

The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. -[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]].  Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the current captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].

 {{Main|Sport in Ukraine}}
 Ukraine greatly benefitted from the Soviet emphasis on [[physical education]], which left Ukraine with hundreds of stadiums, swimming pools, gymnasiums, and many other athletic facilities.

Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].
+[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]]. The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].
 
 Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the current captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -32,7 +32,7 @@
 
 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|Ковбаса́, ''Kovbasa''}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]], [[pilaf]], and [[vareniki]].
+Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].
 
 ==Art==
llm_output:

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -8,7 +8,7 @@
 
 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating. They play basketball in different ways.
 
 ===Education===
 {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}

changed_version:
---

@@ -48,7 +48,7 @@
 On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].

- Sex{{Culture of Ukraine}}
+{{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' and customs of [[Ukraine]] and ethnic [[Ukrainians]]. Ukraine has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, dating back to the 9th century and the [[Rus (name)|Land of Rus]]. Mutual customs are shared among the cultures of  [[Ukraine]], [[Culture of Belarus|Belarus]], [[Ukrainian Cossacks]] and [[Turkic peoples]] of [[Central Asia]]. Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language.
 
 ==Customs==

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -58,7 +58,7 @@
 For men, traditional dress includes [[Kozhukh]], [[Kontusz]], [[Żupan]] and [[Sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[Vyshyvanka]], [[Kozhushanka]], [[Ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].
+Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].
 
 National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.
llm_output:
Changed the URL in a citation from an archived link to a different archived link.

Not Weaponised – The change is a technical edit to a citation and does not introduce any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@
 
 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
-An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|ua|script=latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
+An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk|script=latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].

+{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"
+
+====Weddings====
+{{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+
 ===Education===
 {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}
 [[File:Cernauti Residentia 04.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Chernivtsi University]].]]

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -56,6 +56,7 @@
 
 ====Traditional costume====
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
+[[File:Вишиванки (Светлана Стоялова).jpg|thumb|Ukrainian woman in Ukrainian clothes]]
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].
llm_output:
Added an image of a Ukrainian woman in traditional clothes.

Not Weaponised. The change enhances the cultural representation of Ukrainian heritage without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

@@ -29,7 +29,7 @@
 
 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
-An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|Ковбаса́, ''Kovbasa''}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
+An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-ua|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|ua|script=latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].

Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. @@ -105,7 +105,7 @@
 
 [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]]. The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].
 
-Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the current captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
+Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]], the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]]. The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
 
 Ukrainian brothers [[Vitaliy Klychko]] and [[Volodymyr Klychko]] have held world heavyweight champion titles in [[boxing]].

 {{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
 [[Image:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
 
-Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
+Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
 * The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
 * Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].

 ===Tourism===
 {{Main|Tourism in Ukraine}}
 Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Туристичні потоки] {{uk icon}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]] and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities, festivals, [[ecotourism]], and [[medical tourism]].
-
-=== '''Ukrainian market - Bazaar''' ===
-Bazaar is well-known mostly for marketplaces of Middle Eastern countries. But Ukrainians usually call an open market with the same word, less often - 'rynok'. Many Ukrainians who has been living during the Soviet Era, remember that Rynok or Bazaar was only one place where people could find all necessary things. Probably, that's why this type of shopping places is still popular in Ukraine. You can find such markets in every Ukrainian city or town.  For example, [[Kiev|Kyiv]], the Ukrainian capital, is full of them and one of the most popular is the [[Besarabsky Market]]. In such markets people sell fresh seasonal vegetables, meat, fish, homemade cottage cheese, second-hand and new clothes, household things, books etc. In case you need something you don't even know where you can find it - just go to the Rynok, or how Ukrainians call it 'Na Bazaar', and ask. People there know everything.
-
-Bazaar or Rynok in Ukraine - it's not only about selling grocery - it is a whole social and even cultural phenomenon. People meet there, talk with each other, share the latest news and gossips. It is a different story how Ukrainian sellers praise and call to buy their goods. Big Ukrainian cities, for example, Kyiv, [[Lviv]], [[Kharkiv]], [[Dnipro]] is also known for the 'spontaneous markets'. It happens when people from countryside around the big city bring their homemade products and sell them in crowded places in the city: near the metro, in the central parts of the city, at the railway stations etc. Walking through the streets of the Ukrainian city you can stumble upon a cute (or not) 'babusya' (grandmother) asking you to buy one or two fresh apples/flowers/pears etc.  
-
-Compared to modern shiny shopping malls, the city’s markets might seem a little bit shabby, but in case you want to feel everyday Ukrainian soul you have definitely visit any Rynok you'll find.{{clear}}
+{{clear}}
 
 ==See also==

 ===Language===
 {{Main|Ukrainian language}}
 The main language is Ukrainian.
+
+===Respect for authority===
+Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the they treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population “The severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following them”. This massive lack of respect is mainly caused by huge distrust for any kind of state governance and its related departments. The latest social research <ref>https://strana.ua/articles/121996-pochemu-rejtinh-vlasti-upal-do-istoricheskoho-minimuma.html</ref> shows that only 12% of the population believes that their leaders and public servants make a good job of managing the county’s internal and external policies. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority.
+
+
 
 ===Religion===
 {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}}

+
+=== '''Ukrainian market - Bazaar''' ===
+Bazaar is well-known mostly for marketplaces of Middle Eastern countries. But Ukrainians usually call an open market with the same word, less often - 'rynok'.  === Paying restaurant bills ===
-In most restaurants in Ukraine, the waiter will bring you your bill when you request for it after you’ve had your meal.
-
-Most of the time the bill doesn’t include a tip, so it’s up to you to decide whether you want to tip the waiter or not. If there is a tip already included, it’s generally around 10 to 13 percent of the cost of your food & drinks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whototip.net/tipping-in-ukraine|website=www.whototip.net|access-date=2018-12-10}}</ref> It is considered quite rude not to leave a tip if the service you received was satisfactory, but if it was terrible or the waiter offended you in some way you are free to only pay for your order.
+In most restaurants in Ukraine, the waiter will bring you your bill when you request for it after you’ve had your meal. Most of the time the bill doesn’t include a tip, so it’s up to you to decide whether you want to tip the waiter or not. If there is a tip already included, it’s generally around 10 to 13 percent of the cost of your food & drinks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.whototip.net/tipping-in-ukraine|website=www.whototip.net|access-date=2018-12-10}}</ref> It is considered quite rude not to leave a tip if the service you received was satisfactory, but if it was terrible or the waiter offended you in some way you are free to only pay for your order.
 
 You can always split the bill if you need to. In order to do that just let the waiter know you want to split it before you order or before you ask for the bill. Sometimes the drinks and the food might be split into two bills, it’s totally normal, just depends on how the restaurant pays their taxes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://minfin.com.ua/ua/2017/10/09/30354580/|title=Два чеки в ресторані|website=minfin.com.ua|language=uk|access-date=2018-12-10}}</ref> Some restaurants have their own discount policy and hand in the discount cards to their frequent customers. If you’ve purchased enough food in one sitting the waiter will ask you if you would like to receive your discount card and use it in the future.
llm_output:
Removed a section about tipping practices in Ukrainian restaurants.

Not Weaponised. The change is a straightforward removal of content related to restaurant tipping practices, which does not invoke any cultural or political narratives that could be considered weaponisation.

--- +++ @@ -20,13 +20,20 @@ ===Respect for authority=== Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the they treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population “The severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following them”. This massive lack of respect is mainly caused by huge distrust for any kind of state governance and its related departments. The latest social research https://strana.ua/articles/121996-pochemu-rejtinh-vlasti-upal-do-istoricheskoho-minimuma.html shows that only 12% of the population believes that their leaders and public servants make a good job of managing the county’s internal and external policies. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority. - - - ===Religion=== {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}} [[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]] are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/up.html|accessdate=16 March 2012}} is the largest in the country.[http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion] Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. -{{clear}} + +
+ +=== Paying restaurant bills === +In most restaurants in Ukraine, the waiter will bring you your bill when you request for it after you’ve had your meal. + +Most of the time the bill doesn’t include a tip, so it’s up to you to decide whether you want to tip the waiter or not. If there is a tip already included, it’s generally around 10 to 13 percent of the cost of your food & drinks.{{Cite web|url=http://www.whototip.net/tipping-in-ukraine|website=www.whototip.net|access-date=2018-12-10}} It is considered quite rude not to leave a tip if the service you received was satisfactory, but if it was terrible or the waiter offended you in some way you are free to only pay for your order. + +You can always split the bill if you need to. In order to do that just let the waiter know you want to split it before you order or before you ask for the bill. Sometimes the drinks and the food might be split into two bills, it’s totally normal, just depends on how the restaurant pays their taxes.{{Cite web|url=http://minfin.com.ua/ua/2017/10/09/30354580/|title=Два чеки в ресторані|website=minfin.com.ua|language=uk|access-date=2018-12-10}} Some restaurants have their own discount policy and hand in the discount cards to their frequent customers. If you’ve purchased enough food in one sitting the waiter will ask you if you would like to receive your discount card and use it in the future. + +Paying with your card is a very popular option in Kyiv and other big Ukrainian cities. Since 2006 all department stores in Ukraine were requested to provide their customers with a possibility of paying with their credit cards. Soon after that a lot of restaurants and cafés adopted this custom and now you can pay with your card (or your phone, using ApplePay or GooglePay) in most restaurants and stores in Kyiv. Some waiters ask you what you paying method will be before they bring your bill, but if they don’t you have to let them know you’ll be paying with your card so they can bring the terminal over to your table. {{clear}} ==Cuisine== [[File:Borscht_served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]] {{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}
llm_output:
Added a section titled "Paying restaurant bills" with detailed information about tipping practices and payment methods in Ukrainian restaurants.

Not Weaponised – The content is neutral and informative, focusing on cultural practices related to dining in Ukraine without any political or contentious language.

 {{Main|List of Ukrainian painters|Ukrainian avant-garde}}
 
 ====Traditional costume====
-For men, traditional dress includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[vyshyvanka]], [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
+The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -37,6 +37,18 @@
 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].
+
+This detailed list should be started with borshch. This soup made of meat, beetroot, potato, cabbage and many other ingredients is one of the main dishes associated with Ukraine. There’s no family who don’t cook it on the weekends. There are a lot of different variants of this dish depending on the region of Ukraine, tastes or a chef, but it always tastes best when served with sour cream, bread and salo.
+
+Another famous dish is Chicken Kyiv, named after capital of Ukraine This dish made of chicken filet with a piece of butter and dill inside is famous across the world nowadays. It is even served in some fashionable restaurants in Europe and the USA.
+
+One more famous dish is varenyky. It is not only Ukrainian dish because in some countries it is also known as pierogi, but in Ukraine it tastes the best :)Іt is a kind of dumpling made of dough, but the filling depends on the imagination and taste preferences of the chef or family. Cabbages, meat, mushrooms, potatoes, cottage cheese, cherries or strawberry are the most typical fillings.
+
+Another dish is deruny, or potato pancakes, which may be fried or baked. They mostly are served with meat, mushrooms, onion or other additional ingredients. Also you can keep them simple and serve just with sour cream.
+
+One more Ukrainian national dish is golubtsi - traditional stuffed cabbage rolls. They take many hours to prepare properly and there are two ways to make them: bake them in the oven or stew them in a pan. Minced meat with rice wrapped in cabbage leaf requires fine culinary skills, but Ukrainian mothers and grandmothers do them perfectly!
+
+Among other national ukrainian dishes there are so many delicious ones, like pampushky, holodets, syrnyky, nalysnyky and many others, because Ukraine is rich in it.
 
 ==Art==
llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a detailed description of various traditional Ukrainian dishes, including borshch, Chicken Kyiv, varenyky, deruny, and golubtsi, along with their preparation and cultural significance.

Not Weaponised – The content focuses on the culinary heritage of Ukraine without invoking any political narratives or contentious terms. It celebrates Ukrainian culture through its cuisine, which is a neutral aspect of cultural heritage.

changed_version:
--- +++ @@ -26,15 +26,7 @@ ===Religion=== {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}} [[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]] are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/up.html|accessdate=16 March 2012}} is the largest in the country.[http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion] Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are united with the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. - -
- -=== '''Ukrainian market - Bazaar''' === -Bazaar is well-known mostly for marketplaces of Middle Eastern countries. But Ukrainians usually call an open market with the same word, less often - 'rynok'. Many Ukrainians who has been living during the Soviet Era, remember that Rynok or Bazaar was only one place where people could find all necessary things. Probably, that's why this type of shopping places is still popular in Ukraine. You can find such markets in every Ukrainian city or town.  For example, [[Kiev|Kyiv]], the Ukrainian capital, is full of them and one of the most popular is the [[Besarabsky Market]]. In such markets people sell fresh seasonal vegetables, meat, fish, homemade cottage cheese, second-hand and new clothes, household things, books etc{{Cite web|url=https://www.aimrealtykiev.com/guide-to-kievs-farmers-markets-and-bazaars/|title=Guide to Kiev's Farmer's Markets and Bazaars|date=2015-03-24|language=en-US|access-date=2018-12-10}}. In case you need something you don't even know where you can find it - just go to the Rynok, or how Ukrainians call it 'Na Bazaar', and ask. People there know everything. - -Bazaar or Rynok in Ukraine - it's not only about selling grocery - it is a whole social and even cultural phenomenon. People meet there, talk with each other, share the latest news and gossips. It is a different story how Ukrainian sellers praise and call to buy their goods. Big Ukrainian cities, for example, Kyiv, [[Lviv]], [[Kharkiv]], [[Dnipro]] is also known for the 'spontaneous markets'. It happens when people from countryside around the big city bring their homemade products and sell them in crowded places in the city: near the metro, in the central parts of the city, at the railway stations etc. Walking through the streets of the Ukrainian city you can stumble upon a cute (or not) 'babusya' (grandmother) asking you to buy one or two fresh apples/flowers/pears etc.   - -Compared to modern shiny shopping malls, the city’s markets might seem a little bit shabby, but in case you want to feel everyday Ukrainian soul you have definitely visit any Rynok you'll find{{Cite web|url=https://www.kyivpost.com/lifestyle/kyivs-markets-offer-homegrown-food-secondhand-treasures-books-much.html|title=Kyiv’s markets offer homegrown food, secondhand treasures, books and much more|date=2017-10-13|website=KyivPost|access-date=2018-12-10}}.{{clear}} +{{clear}} ==Cuisine== [[File:Borscht_served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]] {{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}

 ===Respect for authority===
-Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the way treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population “The severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following them”. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority.

@@ -74,7 +74,7 @@
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].
+Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].
 
 National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.

The countries strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
+
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the countries unique positions its culture has been influenced by both Western Europe, Russia and Asia.
+
+Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past have often implemented policies aimed at integrating the endemic population into their occupiers own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture for example the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
+
+Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ to their Gregorian counterparts, these include Christmas and New Years Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
+

@@ -74,7 +74,7 @@
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archivedate=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav-Khmelnytskyi]].

[[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].
 
 National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |date= |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.

@@ -84,7 +84,7 @@
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
+* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
 * Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].

According to modern Russian ethnic studies and historiography Ukrainian culture and Ukrainian nation is part of bigger [[triune Russian nation]], where Russians are dominant ethnic group and Ukrainians are simply its regional branch. At the same time Ukrainian culture has a lot of commonalities with [[Polish culture]] and [[Belarusian culture]], due to being related for many centuries to the former [[Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth]]. In addition Ukrainian culture has special relations with Moldavian culture which is part of bigger [[Vlach nation]] today politically realized as country of [[Romania]].

 The main language is Ukrainian.
 
 ===Respect for authority===
-Ukrainians have almost zero respect for authority. It can be seen in the they treat their government, for instance how they throw rotten eggs at them when people are dissatisfied with something or how they make up memes and jokes when politicians make some mistakes in any activity. Ukrainians also tend to ignore a lot of rules because of the absence of fear of being punished by authority. There is also a popular saying amongst population “The severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following them”. Moreover, corruption in Ukraine thrives extremely, especially in the sphere of governance of any kind, so it also facilitates deeper disrespect for authority.

The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
 The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kievan Rus']] centered in [[Kiev]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. +[[File:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].

 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].

-Ukrainian literature had a difficult development because, due to constant foreign domination over [[Ukraine|Ukrainian territories]], there was often a significant difference between the spoken and written language.  ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
 
-Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

 {{More citations needed|date=October 2019}}{{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is a composition of material and spiritual values of [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its history ([[Ukrainian history]]). It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kyiv]] and region around it.
 
-Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's rich literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]] and [[Ivan Franko]]. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1991.
+Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's rich literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]] and [[Ivan Franko]]. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1992.
 
 The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kyivan Rus.

 ====Weddings====
