-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celethe stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
 
 ===Education===
 {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}

 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.

@@ -73,9 +73,9 @@
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]], is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May. For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|accessdate=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. -National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |accessdate=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. ---

@@ -11,7 +11,7 @@
 
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
 
-Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.
 
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]],and [[pilaf]].

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country.  [[File:Borscht served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
 {{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}
 {{See also|Ukrainian wine}}
-
 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.

changed_version:
---

@@ -4,20 +4,20 @@
 
 Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]] and [[Ivan Franko]]. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
-The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kyivan Rus. 
+The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors. Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
 
 Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the country's location its culture has been influenced by both Europe and Asia.
 
-Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
+Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominatedhe country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
 
 ==Customs==
 ===Holidays and celebrations ===
 [[File:Shepherds Bow - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] icon, [[Adoration of the Shepherds]], from the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]] collection. Artist unknown, c. 1670.]]
-{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"
+{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie|Koledowanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"
 
 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
@@ -60,7 +60,7 @@
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 [[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. 
+On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning. From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]] to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden. Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. 
 
 ====Jewelry====
 [[File:Carpatho-Rusyn sub-groups - Transcarpathian Rusyns in original goral folk-costumes from Maramureş ..jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in national dress]]
@@ -85,7 +85,7 @@
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
 * The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.
-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].
+* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia|pryvitannya]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].
 
 ====Music====
 {{Main|Music of Ukraine}}

 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Because of the country's location its culture has been influenced by both Europe and Asia.
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]] and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]]. 
 
-Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture. 
+Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. 
+On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]].  {{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]]. It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kyiv]] and region around it.<ref name="Conv_Kyiv">{{cite web |title=Ukraine as a ‘borderland’ |url=https://theconversation.com/ukraine-as-a-borderland-a-brief-history-of-ukraines-place-between-europe-and-russia-178168 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
+Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
-The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
+The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus.
 
-Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself.

-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity.  Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>

-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. @@ -85,7 +85,7 @@
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.<ref name="Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Chervona Kalyna |url=https://kalyna.org/ |website=Kalyna |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].<ref name="UNF_Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Kalyna Performing Arts Company |url=https://unfcanada.ca/programs/kalyna/ |website=UNF Canada |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[Boot|boots]], but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
+* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boot]]s, but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
 * Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia|pryvitannya]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].<ref name="Brit_Hopak">{{cite web |title=Hopak |url=https://www.britannica.com/art/hopak |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]].<ref name="Bets_Vyscha">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Vyscha Liga |url=https://betsapi.com/l/151/Ukraine-Vyscha-Liga |website=BetsAPI |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].
 
-Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]],<ref name="CBC_goldball">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Andriy Shevchenko wins Golden Ball |url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/ukrainian-andriy-shevchenko-wins-golden-ball-1.480117 |website=CBC |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]].<ref name="Hyper_cap">{{cite web |title=List of Ukraine national football team captains |url=https://hyperleap.com/topic/List_of_Ukraine_national_football_team_captains |website=Hyperleap |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].{{cn|date=March 2022}}

 Ukrainian brothers [[Vitaliy Klychko]] and [[Volodymyr Klychko]] have held world heavyweight champion titles in [[boxing]].<ref name="KM_Klitschko">{{cite web |title=Klitschko Museum |url=https://klitschkomuseum.com/en/about |website=Klitschko Museum |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The change is technical in nature, focusing on citation accuracy rather than altering the content or narrative related to cultural heritage.

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.

-Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts. These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
+Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

+{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie|Koledowanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"<ref name="IE_Razom">{{cite web |title=Ukraine’s fight for a democratic future |url=https://isiseurope.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/the-russian-way-or-the-highway-ukraines-fight-for-a-democratic-future/ |website=Isis Europe |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ====Weddings====
 {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.
+Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message. After they reach an agreement, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 [[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
 
-An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete." -Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. -* The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach.  ====Literature====
 {{Main|Ukrainian literature}}
 
-Ukrainian literature had a difficult development because, due to constant foreign domination over [[Ukraine|Ukrainian territories]], there was often a significant difference between the spoken and written language. At times the use of the Ukrainian language was even partly prohibited to be [[Ems Ukaz|printed]]. However, foreign rule by [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Austria-Hungary]], and the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turkey]], left behind new words thereby enriching Ukrainian. Despite tsarist and Soviet repression, Ukrainian authors were able to produce a rich literary heritage.
+Ukrainian literature had a difficult development because, due to constant foreign domination over [[Ukraine|Ukrainian territories]], there was often a significant difference between the spoken and written language. At times the use of the Ukrainian language was even partly prohibited to be [[Ems Ukaz|printed]]. However, foreign rule by [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Russia]], [[Austria-Hungary]], and the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turkey]], left behind new words thereby enriching Ukrainian.<ref name="Brit_lang">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian language |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Ukrainian-language |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Despite tsarist and Soviet repression, Ukrainian authors were able to produce a rich literary heritage.<ref name="Brit_lit">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian literature |url=https://www.britannica.com/art/Ukrainian-literature |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-Many Ukrainians also contributed to the closely related [[Russian literature|literature in Russian language]].
+Many Ukrainians also contributed to the closely related [[Russian literature|literature in Russian language]].<ref name="UIL_lit">{{cite web |title=Ukraine’s distinctive Russian-language culture |url=https://ukrainianinstitute.org.uk/ukraines-distinctive-russian-language-culture-an-evening-with-andrey-kurkov/ |website=Ukrainian Institute London |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].

 ===Tourism===

-Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Туристичні потоки] {{in lang|uk}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]] and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]] are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities, festivals, [[ecotourism]], and [[medical tourism]].

llm_output:
The change made in this revision is the addition of multiple references throughout the article, enhancing the citations for various claims and statements. 

Weaponised: Not Weaponised. The changes primarily involve adding references to support existing content, which does not inherently alter the narrative or introduce weaponisation of cultural heritage.

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -3,13 +3,13 @@
 {{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]]. It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kyiv]] and region around it.<ref name="Conv_Kyiv">{{cite web |title=Ukraine as a ‘borderland’ |url=https://theconversation.com/ukraine-as-a-borderland-a-brief-history-of-ukraines-place-between-europe-and-russia-178168 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]]<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>. The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
+Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
 The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus. 
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself. 
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]]<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>. The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
 
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 [[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine|Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine.]] 
+On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]].

@@ -71,7 +71,7 @@
 {{Main|List of Ukrainian painters|Ukrainian avant-garde|Ukrainian underground}}
 
 ====Traditional costume====
-The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]]<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |website=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>, is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
+The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |website=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].

 {{Culture of Ukraine}}
 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]]. It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on [[history of Kyiv]] and region around it.<ref name="Conv_Kyiv">{{cite web |title=Ukraine as a ‘borderland’ |url=https://theconversation.com/ukraine-as-a-borderland-a-brief-history-of-ukraines-place-between-europe-and-russia-178168 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgenc<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> e since the establishment of independence in 1991.
+Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> since the establishment of independence in 1991.
 
 The modern Ukrainian culture is believed to be formed as a descendant of the ancient state of [[Kyivan Rus']] centered in [[Kyiv]] as well the [[Kingdom of Galicia–Volhynia]], both of which Ukrainians claim as their historical ancestors.<ref name="Brit_Galicia">{{cite web |title=Galicia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Galicia-historical-region-Eastern-Europe |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="Brit_Volhynia">{{cite web |title=Volhynia |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Volhynia |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Therefore, it has a shared culture and history with neighboring nations, such as [[Belarusians]] and [[Russians]]. Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraines historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus.

-The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |website=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. +The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |website=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].
 
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio]</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.

 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]]. @@ -42,9 +42,9 @@
 Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message, if a pumpkin is given then the bridegroom can find one of the friends of the bride to see who is interested and begin the courtship process again if he finds one of the friends of the girlfriend is interested if the parents of the girlfriend gave a pumpkin, (this is specifically a Ukrainian traditional custom), the parents they usually ask for a moment before giving a final reply to see if the daughter is interested in private without the boyfriend being present while he is waiting in the guestroom. living room for the reply, if the girlfriend is not interested or if the parents find the man unsuitable for their daughter, then the father comes forward and gives a pumpkin, but even though a pumpkin is not the end of the world, for the boyfriend means the end of a relationship and that means that one of the friends of the bride he can show his interest, in that case and see if one of them is interested in him then they begin the relationship, still nowadays the tradition is the relationship ideally between the courtship process all the way to marriage should no longer than 2 years.

+in Ukrainian culture nowadays as well as most Slavic and eastern cultures it is considered very rude for someone younger, even if they are not part of the same family, to question parents.
 
 once the young man and young woman reach an agreement , as long as the pumpkin is not given and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries an wedding icon the lady carries the Virgin Mary and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 '''Ukrainian culture''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout its [[Ukrainian history|history]].  ==History==
-Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. -There is also a popular saying amongst population “The severity of traffic rules in our country is compensated by the unnecessity of following them”. This relative lack of respect is mainly caused by huge distrust for any kind of state governance and its related departments. The latest social research<ref>{{cite web |url=https://strana.today/articles/121996-pochemu-rejtinh-vlasti-upal-do-istoricheskoho-minimuma.html |title = Почему рейтинг власти упал до исторического минимума}}</ref> shows that only 12% of the population believes that their leaders and public servants make a good job of managing the county's internal and external policies.  {{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there's a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for [[Bride price|ransom]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message, if a pumpkin is given then the bridegroom can find one of the friends of the bride to see who is interested and begin the courtship process again if he finds one of the friends of the girlfriend is interested if the parents of the girlfriend gave a pumpkin, (this is specifically a Ukrainian traditional custom), the parents they usually ask for a moment before giving a final reply to see if the daughter is interested in private without the boyfriend being present while he is waiting in the guestroom. living room for the reply, if the girlfriend is not interested or if the parents find the man unsuitable for their daughter, then the father comes forward and gives a pumpkin, but even though a pumpkin is not the end of the world, for the boyfriend means the end of a relationship and that means that one of the friends of the bride he can show his interest, in that case and see if one of them is interested in him then they begin the relationship, still nowadays the tradition is the relationship ideally between the courtship process all the way to marriage should no longer than 2 years.

 once the young man and young woman reach an agreement , as long as the pumpkin is not given and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries an wedding icon the lady carries the Virgin Mary and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom.
