Religion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.
+[[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]]ism are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/|access-date=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 ==Cuisine==
 [[File:Borscht served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
 {{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}
 {{See also|Ukrainian wine}}
-[[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.
+[[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 An average Ukrainian diet consists of [[Fish (food)|fish]], [[cheese]], and a variety of [[sausages]]. [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''Kolbasa'' ({{lang-uk|Ковбаса́}}, {{lang|uk-latn|Kovbasa}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete".<ref name="EoU_Foods">{{cite web |title=Traditional foods |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CT%5CR%5CTraditionalfoods.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.<ref name="UA_Pysanka">{{cite web |title=Pysanka |url=http://www.artsrn.ualberta.ca/ukisite/ukisite/pysanka/pysanka.htm |website=University of Alberta |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]], and [[pilaf]].
+Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]], and [[pilaf]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 ==Art==
 [[File:Маріїнський палац в Києві.jpg|thumb|[[Mariinskyi Palace]]]]
 
 ===Architecture ===
 {{Main|Ukrainian architecture}}
-Ukrainian architecture reflects distinct features of that particular location and time period. Design and architecture are influenced by the existing political and economic climate.
+Ukrainian architecture reflects distinct features of that particular location and time period. Design and architecture are influenced by the existing political and economic climate.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 ====Vernacular architecture====
 Different regions in Ukraine have their own distinctive style of [[vernacular architecture]], based on local traditions and the knowledge handed down through generations.<ref name="EoU_Arch">{{cite web |title=Folk architecture |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CF%5CO%5CFolkarchitecture.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Museum of Folk Architecture and Way of Life of Central [[Naddnipryanshchyna]] is located in [[Pereiaslav]]. The open-air museum contains 13 theme museums, 122 examples of national architecture, and over 30,000 historical cultural objects.<ref name="KI_FolkMuseum">{{cite web |title=Museum of Folk Architecture  and Rural Life |url=https://www.kiev.info/culture/folk_architecture.htm |website=Kiev.info |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Museum of Decorative Finishes is one of the featured museums that preserves the handiwork of decorative architectural applications in [[Ukrainian architecture]]. Decorative finishes use ancient traditional design patterns.<ref name="EoU_DecArt">{{cite web |title=National Museum of Ukrainian Decorative Folk Art |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CN%5CA%5CNationalMuseumofUkrainianDecorativeFolkArt.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 [[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]].

Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in [[Petrykivsky Painting|Petrykivka Painting]], ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed by [[UNESCO]] as part of the [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}

 {{Main|List of Ukrainian painters|Ukrainian avant-garde|Ukrainian underground}}
 
 ====Traditional costume====

+Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>[http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm Ukrainian Museum Archives. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name="Rivne_Krupove">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ===Performance art===
 ====Dance====
 {{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
-[[File:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine". |right]]
+[[File:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine".{{Citation needed|reason=Source please.|date=August 2022}}|right]]
 
 Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.<ref name="Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Chervona Kalyna |url=https://kalyna.org/ |website=Kalyna |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 * The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly [[Ukrainian embroidery|embroidered]] white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].<ref name="UNF_Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Kalyna Performing Arts Company |url=https://unfcanada.ca/programs/kalyna/ |website=UNF Canada |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

-[[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].

comment: Lots of unsourced claims. Much of this may well be true, but just needs RS for verification. We need to be wary of recent insertions which appear to be politically motivated, but are not based on reliable sources. Especially the weddings subsection seems full of personal opinions.
llm_output:
**Change Description:** Added references for improvement and citations needed in various sections, including the weddings subsection.

**Analysis:** The revision includes a focus on the need for reliable sources and verification of claims, particularly in a politically sensitive context. The user’s comment indicates a concern about unsourced claims that may be politically motivated. The addition of citation requests suggests an effort to ensure the integrity of the information presented, which is crucial in discussions surrounding cultural heritage, especially in contexts of conflict or political tension.

**Conclusion:** Not Weaponised. The changes aim to enhance the reliability of the content rather than promote a specific political narrative or agenda.

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.

 ==History==

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.

 Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[pierogi]], and [[pilaf]].

@@ -9,11 +9,16 @@
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself.
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The [[Soviet era]] unified the cultures of many unrelated nations with a common language and led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics' culture and identity. Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [Ukranian Greek Catholicism], [Ruthenian greek catholicism] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
+Prior to soviet Union, the Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
+
+The [[Soviet era]] almost erased the cultures, to set a new culture and tried to blend many unrelated nations with a common language and a new country called soviet union which led to the appropriation of many of the socialist republics' culture and identity.
+
+However despite the fact that Soviets tried to eradicate different cultures in the so called 'name' to supposedly unify cultures into one new nation. many Ukrainians still retained their traditions and customs privately
 
 {{Multiple image
 | direction         = horizontal
llm_output:
The change involves the addition of several sentences that elaborate on the influence of Ukrainian Greek Catholicism and the impact of the Soviet era on Ukrainian culture. Specifically, the revision adds details about the cultural influences prior to the Soviet Union and emphasizes the attempts of the Soviets to erase distinct cultures while noting that many Ukrainians retained their traditions.

Weaponised. The added content highlights the Soviet efforts to suppress Ukrainian culture, framing it within a narrative of cultural survival against oppression, which can be seen as a response to current geopolitical tensions.

changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -15,6 +15,7 @@
 The '''culture of Ukraine''' is the composite of the material and spiritual values of the [[Ukrainian people]] that has formed throughout the [[history of Ukraine]]. It is closely intertwined with [[ethnic studies]] about ethnic Ukrainians and Ukrainian [[historiography]] which is focused on the [[history of Kyiv]] and the region around it.<ref name="Conv_Kyiv">{{cite web |title=Ukraine as a 'borderland' |url=https://theconversation.com/ukraine-as-a-borderland-a-brief-history-of-ukraines-place-between-europe-and-russia-178168 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ==History==
+[[File:Pektoral111.JPG|thumb|Gold Pectoral from [[Tovsta Mohyla]]|alt=Gold ornament of the Scythian era discovered at Tovsta Mohyla]]
 Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Ivan Kotliarevsky]], [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>{{fv|date=August 2022}} since the establishment of independence in 1991.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 The earliest evidence of [[Cultural artifact|cultural artefacts]] in the Ukrainian lands can be traced to decorated [[mammoth]] tusks in the Neanderthal era.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=24}} Later, the [[Nomad|nomadic tribes]] of the southern lands of the 4th century BCE, like the [[Scythians]], produced finely worked gold ornaments such as the pectoral found in the [[Tovsta Mohyla]] mound.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=25}}
llm_output:
Added an image reference for the "Gold Pectoral from Tovsta Mohyla" in the History section.

Not Weaponised – The addition of the image reference enhances the cultural context of Ukrainian heritage without introducing any politically charged language or narratives.

 ==Customs==
 ===Holidays and celebrations ===
 [[File:Shepherds Bow - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] icon, [[Adoration of the Shepherds]], from the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]] collection. Artist unknown, c. 1670.]]
+[[File:Фестиваль «Спалах Різдвяної звізди 2017".jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in [[Lviv]] celebrate Christmas with traditional [[Koliada]] festival "The flash of Christmas star".]] 
 {{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Ivan Kupala Day]], [[Maslenitsa]], [[Koledovanie|Koledowanie]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups. "[[Razom nas bahato, nas ne podolaty]]" is a popular cultural and political statement of both traditional and modern Ukrainians. It translates as "Together we are many! We cannot be defeated!"<ref name="IE_Razom">{{cite web |title=Ukraine's fight for a democratic future |url=https://isiseurope.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/the-russian-way-or-the-highway-ukraines-fight-for-a-democratic-future/ |website=Isis Europe |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Unlike the West where people can question the parents, in Ukrainian culture if the boyfriend is given a pumpkin he cannot ask why he was declined.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}} some parents might give the answer some might not.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}} However, that means that the groom he has to respect it and move on.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}} In Ukrainian culture as well as most Slavic and Eastern cultures it is considered very rude for someone younger, even if they are not part of the same family, to question parents.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
-Once the young man and young woman reach an agreement and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries an wedding icon the lady carries the Theotokos and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
+Once the young man and young woman reach an agreement and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries a wedding icon the lady carries the Theotokos and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ===Education===
 {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}

Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Ivan Kotliarevsky]], [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=August 2022}} since the establishment of independence in 1991.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 The earliest evidence of [[Cultural artifact|cultural artefacts]] in the Ukrainian lands can be traced to decorated [[mammoth]] tusks in the Neanderthal era.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=24}} Later, the [[Nomad|nomadic tribes]] of the southern lands of the 4th century BCE, like the [[Scythians]], produced finely worked gold ornaments such as the pectoral found in the [[Tovsta Mohyla]] mound.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=25}}

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -102,7 +102,7 @@
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[Lace|lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>{{Cite web |url=http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |title=Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio |access-date=2011-07-04 |archive-date=2009-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324034224/http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Музей українського рушника |url=https://perejaslav.org.ua/places/muzey-ukraynskogo-rushnika.html |website=Переяслав |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name="Rivne_Krupove">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=ui}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>
+National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. @@ -29,7 +29,7 @@
 
 Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholicism]], [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church|Ruthenian Greek Catholicism]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
 Prior to the [[Soviet Union]], the Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-gay
+
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -162,7 +162,7 @@
 Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Туристичні потоки] {{in lang|uk}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine#Seven Natural Wonders|Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="CT_7NatWonders">{{cite web |title=The 7 Natural Wonders of Ukraine |url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/the-7-natural-wonders-of-ukraine/ |website=Culture Trip |date=31 October 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="WA_7wonders">{{cite web |title=The Seven Wonders Of Ukraine |url=https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/the-seven-wonders-of-ukraine.html |website=World Atlas |date=August 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities,<ref name="UES_cities">{{cite web |title=Cities of Ukraine |url=https://uesukraine.com/cities-of-ukraine/ |website=UES Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> festivals,<ref name="iE_fest">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Holidays and Festivals |url=https://www.iexplore.com/articles/travel-guides/europe/ukraine/festivals-and-events |website=iExplore |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> [[ecotourism]],<ref name="VU_eco">{{cite web |title=Ecotourism in Ukraine |url=https://visittoukraine.com/ecotourism-in-ukraine/ |website=Visit to Ukraine |date=12 May 2021 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[medical tourism]].<ref name="HT_Med">{{cite web |title=Medical Tourism to Ukraine |url=https://www.health-tourism.com/medical-tourism-ukraine/ |website=Health Tourism |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 == Impact on culture due to Russian aggression ==
-During the Russian aggression against Ukraine, not only Ukrainian citizens and infrastructure, but also cultural [[heritage]] were targeted by the enemy. Destruction of monuments, attacks on educational and cultural institutions, robbery of museums - this is far from a complete list of crimes. Their number and the testimony of the employees of the affected institutions prove that it is not about individual excesses, but about a systematic and purposeful policy. Cultural heritage was targeted by the occupiers not by chance, but through purposeful [[Culture|cultural]] [[racism]].
+During the Russian aggression against Ukraine, not only Ukrainian citizens and infrastructure, but also cultural [[Cultural heritage|heritage]] were targeted by the enemy. Destruction of monuments, attacks on educational and cultural institutions, robbery of museums - this is far from a complete list of crimes. Their number and the testimony of the employees of the affected institutions prove that it is not about individual excesses, but about a systematic and purposeful policy. Cultural heritage was targeted by the occupiers not by chance, but through purposeful [[Culture|cultural]] [[racism]].
 During the year of the full-scale war, 1,332 objects of cultural infrastructure were destroyed: [[Theatre|theaters]], [[philharmonic]] halls, [[Museum|museums]], [[galleries]], [[Library|libraries]], [[Club|clubs]]. More than a third of them are destroyed. As of mid-May 2023, the list of destroyed cultural monuments and objects of cultural heritage included more than 620 items.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Russians damage 1,946 cultural landmarks in two years of full-scale war against Ukraine |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2024/03/7/7445420/ |access-date=2024-03-10 |website=Ukrainska Pravda |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==See also==

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -27,7 +27,7 @@
 
 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
-Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholicism]], [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church|Ruthenian Greek Catholicism]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
+Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church|Ukrainian Greek Catholicism]], [[Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church|Ruthenian Greek Catholicism]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church]]<ref name="ARDA_Orth">{{cite web |title=Orthodox Christians |url=https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |website=ARDA |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-date=11 April 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100411090638/https://www.thearda.com/internationalData/countries/Country_231_2.asp |url-status=dead }}</ref> and traditions from [[Slavic mythology]].<ref name="Brit_SlavRel">{{cite web |title=Britannica |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Slavic-religion |website=Slavic religion |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> 
 Prior to the [[Soviet Union]], the Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
@@ -61,7 +61,7 @@
 
 ===Religion===
 {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}}
-[[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]]ism are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/|access-date=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
+[[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]]ism are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/|access-date=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |title=Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2010-05-04 |archive-date=2010-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904054142/http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 ==Cuisine==
 [[File:Borscht served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
@@ -102,7 +102,7 @@
 ====Weaving and embroidery====
 Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[Lace|lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>{{Cite web |url=http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |title=Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio |access-date=2011-07-04 |archive-date=2009-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324034224/http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Музей українського рушника |url=https://perejaslav.org.ua/places/muzey-ukraynskogo-rushnika.html |website=Переяслав |language=uk}}</ref>
 
-National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name="Rivne_Krupove">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=uk}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>
+National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30 |archive-date=2007-10-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031043251/http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name="Rivne_Krupove">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=uk}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>
 
 ===Performance art===
 ====Dance====
@@ -149,7 +149,7 @@
 
 [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in Ukraine. The top professional league is the [[Vyscha Liha]], also known as the [[Ukrainian Premier League]].<ref name="Bets_Vyscha">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Vyscha Liga |url=https://betsapi.com/l/151/Ukraine-Vyscha-Liga |website=BetsAPI |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The two most successful teams in the Vyscha Liha are rivals [[FC Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]]. Although Shakhtar is the reigning champion of the Vyscha Liha, Dynamo Kyiv has been much more successful historically, winning the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] two times, the [[UEFA Super Cup]] once, the [[Soviet Top League|USSR Championship]] a record 13 times, and the [[Ukrainian Premier League|Ukrainian Championship]] a record 12 times; while Shakhtar only won four Ukrainian Championships and one and last [[UEFA Cup]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
-Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]],<ref name="CBC_goldball">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Andriy Shevchenko wins Golden Ball |url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/ukrainian-andriy-shevchenko-wins-golden-ball-1.480117 |website=CBC |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]].<ref name="Hyper_cap">{{cite web |title=List of Ukraine national football team captains |url=https://hyperleap.com/topic/List_of_Ukraine_national_football_team_captains |website=Hyperleap |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].{{citation needed|date=March 2022}}
+Many Ukrainians also played for the [[USSR national football team]], most notably [[Igor Belanov]] and [[Oleg Blokhin]], winners of the prestigious [[Ballon d'Or|Golden Ball Award]] for the best footballers of the year. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the collapse of the Soviet Union, [[Andriy Shevchenko]],<ref name="CBC_goldball">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Andriy Shevchenko wins Golden Ball |url=https://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/ukrainian-andriy-shevchenko-wins-golden-ball-1.480117 |website=CBC |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> the former captain of the [[Ukraine national football team]].<ref name="Hyper_cap">{{cite web |title=List of Ukraine national football team captains |url=https://hyperleap.com/topic/List_of_Ukraine_national_football_team_captains |website=Hyperleap |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220307091535/https://hyperleap.com/topic/List_of_Ukraine_national_football_team_captains |url-status=dead }}</ref> The national team made its debut in the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]], and reached the quarter-finals before losing to eventual champions, [[Italy national football team|Italy]].{{citation needed|date=March 2022}}
 
 Ukrainian brothers [[Vitali Klitschko|Vitaliy Klychko]] and [[Wladimir Klitschko|Volodymyr Klychko]] have held world heavyweight champion titles in [[boxing]].<ref name="KM_Klitschko">{{cite web |title=Klitschko Museum |url=https://klitschkomuseum.com/en/about |website=Klitschko Museum |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>

Ukrainian historian, academic and politician of the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]], [[Mykhailo Hrushevsky]] referred to Ukraine as ''Ukraine-Rus,'' emphasising Ukraine's historical claim to the ancient state of Kievan Rus.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Hrushevsky, Mykhailo. History of Ukraine-Rus' : vols. 1–10 (in 12 books) |url=http://hrushevsky.nbuv.gov.ua/item/0001716 |access-date=2020-05-16 |website=hrushevsky.nbuv.gov.ua}}</ref>

History of Ukraine-Rus' : vols. 1–10 (in 12 books) |url=http://hrushevsky.nbuv.gov.ua/item/0001716 |access-date=2020-05-16 |website=hrushevsky.nbuv.gov.ua}}</ref>

-====Weddings====
-{{more citations needed|section|date=August 2022}}
-{{Main|Ukrainian wedding traditions}}
-Traditional Ukrainian wedding celebrations have many rituals that involve music and dancing, drinking and eating, and crowds of people. The wedding consists of three separate parts that can last for days or even weeks. First there is a [[Engagement|betrothal]], then a ceremony, followed by a big celebration. The betrothal involves the groom going to the bride's parents to bargain for the [[Bride price|dowry]] he will pay for the bride and to seek the blessing of her parents. There are many stories in Ukrainian folklore of a bride being [[Bride kidnapping|stolen]] without the groom paying ransom. Often, the stolen bride is a willing participant and the couple [[Elopement (marriage)|elopes]] without her parents' permission. Alternatively, the bride can refuse an offer of marriage, in which case, it is customary for the parents to meet the groom at the door with a [[pumpkin]] to convey the message, if a pumpkin is given then the bridegroom can find one of the friends of the bride to see who is interested and begin the courtship process again if he finds one of the friends of the girlfriend is interested if the parents of the girlfriend gave a pumpkin, (this is specifically a Ukrainian traditional custom), the parents they usually ask for a moment before giving a final reply to see if the daughter is interested in private without the boyfriend being present while he is waiting in the guestroom. living room for the reply, if the girlfriend is not interested or if the parents find the man unsuitable for their daughter, then the father comes forward and gives a pumpkin, but even though a pumpkin is not the end of the world, for the boyfriend means the end of a relationship and that means that one of the friends of the bride he can show his interest, in that case and see if one of them is interested in him then they begin the relationship, still nowadays the tradition is the relationship ideally between the courtship process all the way to marriage should no longer than two years.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-Unlike the West where people can question the parents, in Ukrainian culture if the boyfriend is given a pumpkin he cannot ask why he was declined.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2018-11-15 |title=Весілля |url=https://ridna-ukraina.com.ua/traditions/vesillia.html |website=Рідна Україна |language=uk}}</ref> However, that means that the groom has to respect it and move on.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}} In Ukrainian culture, as well as most Slavic and Eastern cultures, it is considered very rude for someone younger, even if they are not part of the same family, to question parents.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-Once the young man and young woman reach an agreement and the parents fully consent and give the blessing, the official [[wedding]] takes place in a church, often in a group ceremony with other couples each one carries a wedding icon the lady carries the Theotokos and the man carries the icon of Our Lord (both icons need to be previously blessed by a priest) once this happens the couple holds the icon as the parents give the blessing to them with another traditional custom. A celebration follows at home with the entire community participating.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weddings at Soyuzivka |url=http://www.weddingsatsoyuzivka.com/traditions.html |website=Ukrainian Wedding Traditions |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-
 ===Education===
 {{Main|Education in Ukraine}}
 [[File:Cernauti Residentia 04.jpg|thumbnail|right|[[Chernivtsi University]].]]
 
-===Language===
-{{Main|Ukrainian language}}
-The main language is Ukrainian. However, most of the Ukrainian citizens also speak Russian.
-Almost all Ukrainians know the Russian language. As for foreign languages, English or German are mainly taught in schools.
-<ref>{{cite web |title=Language data for Ukraine |url=https://translatorswithoutborders.org/language-data-for-ukraine |website=Translators Without Borders |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref><ref name="EoU_lang">{{cite web |title=Ukrainian language |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CU%5CK%5CUkrainianlanguage.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-
 ===Religion===
 {{Main|Religion in Ukraine}}
 [[Religion]] is practiced throughout the country. [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox Christianity]] and [[Eastern Catholic Churches|Eastern Catholicism]] and [[Roman Catholic]]ism are the three most widely practiced religions. The [[Orthodox Church of Ukraine|Ukrainian Orthodox Church]]<ref>{{cite web|title=CIA World Factbook|url=https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/ukraine/|access-date=16 March 2012}}</ref> is the largest in the country.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite web |url=http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |title=Ukraine Culture. Ukraine People. Education. Religion<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2010-05-04 |archive-date=2010-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100904054142/http://www.ukraine-travel-advisor.com/ukraine-culture.html |url-status=dead }}</ref> Faithful of the [[Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church]], the second largest, practice [[Byzantine]] rites, but are in communion with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] which means that they are also fully Catholic.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-==Cuisine==
-[[File:Borscht served.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian [[borscht]] with [[smetana (dairy product)|smetana]]]]
-{{Main|Ukrainian cuisine}}
-{{See also|Ukrainian wine}}
-[[Food]] is an important part to the Ukrainian culture. Special foods are used at [[Easter]], as well as [[Christmas]]. During Christmas, for example, people prepare ''[[kutia]]'', which is a mixture of cooked wheat [[groats]], [[poppy seeds]], [[honey]], and special sweet breads.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Словник української мови в 11 томах |publisher=Наукова думка |editor-last=Білодід |editor-first=Іван |location=Київ |language=uk |chapter=Кутя |chapter-url=http://sum.in.ua/s/kutja}}</ref>
-
-An average Ukrainian diet includes [[cheese]] and a variety of [[sausages]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2023}} [[Head cheese]] is also quite popular in Ukraine, as well as ''kovbasa'' ({{lang-uk|ковбаса|links=no}}), a type of sausage. Typically [[bread]] is a core part of every meal, and must be included for the meal to be "complete".<ref name="EoU_Foods">{{cite web |title=Traditional foods |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CT%5CR%5CTraditionalfoods.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> During Christmas, for example, it is the tradition to have a [[Twelve-dish Christmas Eve supper|twelve-course meal]]. Included at Easter are the famous [[Egg decorating in Slavic culture|pysanky]], which are colored and patterned eggs. Making these eggs is a long process, and they are used for display at the center of the table rather than consumed.<ref name="UA_Pysanka">{{cite web |title=Pysanka |url=http://www.artsrn.ualberta.ca/ukisite/ukisite/pysanka/pysanka.htm |website=University of Alberta |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-
-Ukrainians often toast to good health, linger over their meal, and engage in lively conversation with family and friends. Often they will drink [[tea]] (''[[Masala chai|chai]]''), [[wine]], or [[coffee]] afterwards with a simple dessert, such as a fruit pastry. Popular foods include [[Salo (food)|salo]], [[borscht]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[chicken Kiev]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> [[Pierogi#Ukraine|varenyky]], [[Cabbage roll|holubtsi]], and [[Syrniki|syrnyky]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-08-19 |title=What is traditional food of Ukraine? |url=https://ukraine.ua/faq/how-to-cook-traditional-ukrainian-food/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>
 
 ==Art==
 {{Main|Arts of Ukraine}}
@@ -102,21 +77,6 @@
 [[File:Carpatho-Rusyn sub-groups - Transcarpathian Rusyns in original goral folk-costumes from Maramureş ..jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in national dress]]
 {{Main|Ukrainian national clothing}}
 The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |publisher=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
-
-====Weaving and embroidery====
-Artisan [[textile arts]] play an important role in Ukrainian culture,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/Ukrainian-clothes|title=Ukrainian folk dress. Traditional clothes of Ukraine|publisher=Ua-travelling.com|date=13 July 2010|access-date=30 December 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130725153343/http://ua-travelling.com/en/article/ukrainian-clothes|archive-date=25 July 2013}}</ref> especially in [[Ukrainian wedding traditions]]. [[Ukrainian embroidery]], [[weaving]], and [[Lace|lace-making]] are used in traditional [[folk dress]] and in traditional celebrations.<ref name="UAPOST_Embr">{{cite web |title=Types and symbols of Ukrainian embroidery ornaments |url=https://uapost.us/en/blog/types-and-symbols-of-ukrainian-embroidery-ornaments/ |website=UAPOST.US |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin,<ref>''"Podvyzhnytsi narodnoho mystetstva", Kyiv 2003 and 2005, by Yevheniya Shudra, Welcome to Ukraine Magazine''</ref> and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colors, and types of stitches.<ref name=museum>{{Cite web |url=http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |title=Ukrainian Museum Archives. Online exhibit on loan from the D.Dmytrykiw Ukrainian Ethnographic Research Collection, Library & Archives of Westlake, Ohio |access-date=2011-07-04 |archive-date=2009-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324034224/http://www.umacleveland.org/embroidery.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> Use of color is very important and has roots in [[Ukrainian folklore]]. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the [[Rushnyk]] Museum in [[Pereiaslav]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Музей українського рушника |url=https://perejaslav.org.ua/places/muzey-ukraynskogo-rushnika.html |website=Переяслав |language=uk}}</ref>
-
-National dress is woven and highly decorated. [[Weaving]] with handmade looms is still practiced in the village of Krupove, situated in [[Rivne Oblast]]. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts [[Art fabrication|fabrication]]. Nina Myhailivna<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |title=Рівненська обласна державна адміністрація – Обласний центр народної творчості |publisher=Rv.gov.ua |access-date=2010-12-30 |archive-date=2007-10-31 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031043251/http://www.rv.gov.ua/sitenew/main/ua/1160.htm |url-status=dead }}</ref> and Uliana Petrivna<ref>{{cite web|url=http://storinka-m.kiev.ua/article.php?id=478 |title=ПІСНІ ТА ВИШИВКИ УЛЯНИ КОТ – Мистецька сторінка |publisher=Storinka-m.kiev.ua |access-date=2010-12-30}}</ref> with international recognition. In order to preserve this traditional knowledge, the village is planning to open a local weaving center, museum, and weaving school.<ref name="Rivne_Krupove">{{cite web |title=Weaving and Dumplings |url=https://rivnepost.rv.ua/news/prezentuvali-serpankove-tkatstvo-ta-prihoshchali-hostey-varenikami |website=Rivnepost |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Other centres of embroidery include [[Krolevets]],<ref>{{Cite web |title=Кролевецькі рушники |url=https://lib.knukim.edu.ua/proekti-biblioteki/proekt-skarbi-nacii/krolevecki-rushniki/ |website=Наукова бібліотека КНУКіМ |language=uk}}</ref> [[Reshetylivka]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Batyrieva |first=Iryna |title=Технологія виконання вишивки «білим по білому» селища Решетилівка Решетилівського району Полтавської області |url=https://authenticukraine.com.ua/blog/tehnologia-vikonanna-visivki-bilim-po-bilomu-dopracovanij |website=Authentic Ukraine |language=uk}}</ref> [[Borshchiv]],<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smirashevska |first=Sofia |date=2023-01-27 |title=Фестиваль «Борщівська вишиванка»: історія створення, цікаві дійства та особливості святкування |url=https://ternopilski.info/uk/eternal-4893-festyval-borshhivska-vyshyvanka-istoriya-stvorennya-czikavi-dijstva-ta-osoblyvosti-svyatkuvannya |website=Ternopilski |language=uk}}</ref> Klembivka,<ref>{{Cite web |last=Tytarenko |first=Volodymyr |title=Орнаментні традиції клембівської вишивки |url=https://www.vocnt.org.ua/statti/klembivska_vishivka |website=Вінницький обласний центр народної творчості |language=uk}}</ref> and [[Yavoriv]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Яворівська вишивка |url=http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615133354/http://yavoriv-rada.eu5.org/vyshyvka.html |archive-date=2013-06-15 |website=Яворівська міська рада |language=uk}}</ref>
-
-===Performance art===
-====Dance====
-{{Main|Ukrainian dance}}
-[[File:Rapid Trident 2014 06.jpg|thumb|The [[Hopak]] is often popularly referred to as the "National Dance of Ukraine".{{Citation needed|reason=Source please.|date=August 2022}}|right]]
-
-Traditional dances are popular within Ukraine, many of which derive from rural [[Cossack]] villages.<ref name="ukraine1">[http://www.ukraine.com/culture/ Culture in Ukraine | By Ukraine Channel<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> One Ukrainian style of dancing is called the ''[[Kalyna (dance)|kalyna]]''. Both men and women participate in this type of dancing.<ref name="Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Chervona Kalyna |url=https://kalyna.org/ |website=Kalyna |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The women wear colourful costumes, sometimes featuring a solid-coloured (usually blue, green, red, or black) tunic and matching apron, and under that an open skirt, and below that a white skirt with an embroidered hem that should reach an inch or so below the knee. If they wear a tunic, then under that they wear a long-sleeved richly embroidered white shirt. Traditionally, women wear a type of red leather boots to dance in. They also wear a flower head piece ([[vinok]]), that is a headband covered with [[flowers]] and has long flowing ribbons down the back that flow when they dance, and plain red coral [[necklaces]].<ref name="UNF_Kalyna">{{cite web |title=Kalyna Performing Arts Company |url=https://unfcanada.ca/programs/kalyna/ |website=UNF Canada |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
-* The men wear baggy [[trousers]] (usually blue, white, black or red) and a shirt (usually white, but sometimes black) embroidered at the neck and down the stomach. Over the shirt they sometimes will wear a richly embroidered [[vest]]. Around their waist they wear a thick sash with fringed ends. Like the women, they wear [[boot]]s, but these can be black or white in addition to red.<ref name="UNF_Kalyna"/>
-* Kalyna dancing involves partner dancing. One dance, called the ''[[pryvitannia]]'', is a greeting dance. It is slow and respectful, the women bow to the audience and present bread with [[salt]] on a cloth and flowers. Another, called the [[hopak]] is much more lively, and involves many fast-paced movements. Hence hopak as a dance is derived from hopak martial art of [[Cossacks]].<ref name="Brit_Hopak">{{cite web |title=Hopak |url=https://www.britannica.com/art/hopak |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
 ====Music====
 {{Main|Music of Ukraine}}

The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.

 {{Main|Tourism in Ukraine}}
 Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Туристичні потоки] {{in lang|uk}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine#Seven Natural Wonders|Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="CT_7NatWonders">{{cite web |title=The 7 Natural Wonders of Ukraine |url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/the-7-natural-wonders-of-ukraine/ |website=Culture Trip |date=31 October 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="WA_7wonders">{{cite web |title=The Seven Wonders Of Ukraine |url=https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/the-seven-wonders-of-ukraine.html |website=World Atlas |date=August 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities,<ref name="UES_cities">{{cite web |title=Cities of Ukraine |url=https://uesukraine.com/cities-of-ukraine/ |website=UES Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> festivals,<ref name="iE_fest">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Holidays and Festivals |url=https://www.iexplore.com/articles/travel-guides/europe/ukraine/festivals-and-events |website=iExplore |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> [[ecotourism]],<ref name="VU_eco">{{cite web |title=Ecotourism in Ukraine |url=https://visittoukraine.com/ecotourism-in-ukraine/ |website=Visit to Ukraine |date=12 May 2021 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[medical tourism]].<ref name="HT_Med">{{cite web |title=Medical Tourism to Ukraine |url=https://www.health-tourism.com/medical-tourism-ukraine/ |website=Health Tourism |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
+== Crimean Tatars ==
+[[Crimean Tatars]] are the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] of the [[Crimea]].
+
+=== Music ===
+Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.
+
