initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -34,6 +34,8 @@
 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. For example, the policy of [[Russification of Ukraine|Russification]] posed significant obstacles to the development of the culture.<ref name="Conv_RusUk"/>
 
 Whilst progressing into modernity, Ukraine remains a highly traditional country, where the observance of certain customs and practices play a central role in its culture. Many significant Ukrainian holidays and events are based on the old Julian Calendar and so differ from their Gregorian counterparts.<ref name="EMP_Julian">{{cite web |title=Christmas on January 7 |url=https://euromaidanpress.com/2016/12/25/why-does-ukraine-celebrate-christmas-on-january-7-not-december-25/ |website=Euromaidan Press |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> These include Christmas and New Year's Eve, both of which are highly important in Ukrainian culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/11-things-you-should-know-about-ukrainian-culture/|title=11 Things You Should Know About Ukrainian Culture|last=Sibirtseva|first=Maria|website=Culture Trip|date=17 July 2018|access-date=2019-02-28}}</ref>
+
+During the [[Russo-Ukrainian War#Full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine (2022–present)|invasion of Ukraine by Russia]], damage was caused to 1,945 cultural infrastructure objects, according to Ukraine's Ministry of Culture and Information Policy. Cultural institutions that were damaged or destroyed by Russians include cultural clubs, libraries, museums, galleries, theatres, zoos, and art education institutions. It is estimated that rebuilding the damaged sites may take about 10 years.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Russians damage 1,946 cultural landmarks in two years of full-scale war against Ukraine |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2024/03/7/7445420/ |access-date=2024-03-10 |website=Ukrainska Pravda |language=en}}</ref>
 
 ==Customs==
 ===Holidays and celebrations ===
@@ -162,9 +164,6 @@
 {{Main|Tourism in Ukraine}}
 Ukraine attracts more than 20 million visitors a year from around the world.<ref name=ukrstat>[http://www.ukrstat.gov.ua/operativ/operativ2007/tyr/tyr_u/potoki2006_u.htm Туристичні потоки] {{in lang|uk}}, State Statistics Committee of Ukraine</ref> [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine#Seven Natural Wonders|Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="CT_7NatWonders">{{cite web |title=The 7 Natural Wonders of Ukraine |url=https://theculturetrip.com/europe/ukraine/articles/the-7-natural-wonders-of-ukraine/ |website=Culture Trip |date=31 October 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[Seven Wonders of Ukraine]]<ref name="WA_7wonders">{{cite web |title=The Seven Wonders Of Ukraine |url=https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/the-seven-wonders-of-ukraine.html |website=World Atlas |date=August 2017 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> are popular destinations as well as modern urban cities,<ref name="UES_cities">{{cite web |title=Cities of Ukraine |url=https://uesukraine.com/cities-of-ukraine/ |website=UES Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> festivals,<ref name="iE_fest">{{cite web |title=Ukraine Holidays and Festivals |url=https://www.iexplore.com/articles/travel-guides/europe/ukraine/festivals-and-events |website=iExplore |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> [[ecotourism]],<ref name="VU_eco">{{cite web |title=Ecotourism in Ukraine |url=https://visittoukraine.com/ecotourism-in-ukraine/ |website=Visit to Ukraine |date=12 May 2021 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> and [[medical tourism]].<ref name="HT_Med">{{cite web |title=Medical Tourism to Ukraine |url=https://www.health-tourism.com/medical-tourism-ukraine/ |website=Health Tourism |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
 
-== Impact on culture due to Russian aggression ==
-During the [[Russo-Ukrainian War#Full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine (2022–present)|invasion of Ukraine by Russia]], damage was caused to 1,945 cultural infrastructure objects, according to Ukraine's Ministry of Culture and Information Policy. Cultural institutions that were damaged or destroyed by Russians include cultural clubs, libraries, museums, galleries, theatres, zoos, and art education institutions. It is estimated that rebuilding the damaged sites may take about 10 years.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Russians damage 1,946 cultural landmarks in two years of full-scale war against Ukraine |url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/eng/news/2024/03/7/7445420/ |access-date=2024-03-10 |website=Ukrainska Pravda |language=en}}</ref>
-
 ==See also==

llm_output:
The change made is the addition of a paragraph detailing the damage caused to cultural infrastructure during the Russo-Ukrainian War, specifically mentioning the number of cultural objects affected and the estimated time for rebuilding. 

Weaponised. The addition emphasizes the impact of Russian actions on Ukrainian cultural heritage, framing it within the context of ongoing conflict and highlighting the destruction as a significant issue, which aligns with narratives of cultural oppression and loss.

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -137,6 +137,39 @@
 
 Today in use there are two types of alphabet: Cyrillic and Latin. Initially Crimean Tatars used Arabic script. In 1928 it was replaced with the Latin alphabet. Cyrillic was introduced in 1938 based on the Russian alphabet. The Cyrillic alphabet was the only official one between 1938 and 1997. All its letters coincide with those of the Russian alphabet. The 1990s saw the start of the gradual transition of the language to the new Latin alphabet based on the Turkish one.<ref>{{Cite web |date=21 March 2017 |title=Crimean Tatars: A to Z |url=https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220223100710/https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |archive-date=23 February 2022 |access-date=23 February 2022}}</ref>
 
+== Canada ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Canadians}}
+First Ukrainians have arrived in Canada in 1891, bringing their Ukrainian traditions with them, which they preserved and propagated, enriching their new home with it, and maintaining their separate ethnicity.<ref>{{Cite thesis |title=Ukrainian cultural traditions in Canada: Theatre, choral music and dance, 1891-1967. |url=http://hdl.handle.net/10393/10564 |publisher=University of Ottawa (Canada) |date=1977 |language=en |first=Alexandra |last=Pritz}}</ref>
+
+Having been separated from Ukraine, Ukrainian Canadians have developed their own distinctive Ukrainian culture in Canada. To showcase their unique hybrid culture, Ukrainian Canadians have created institutions that showcase Ukrainian Canadian culture such as [[Edmonton]]'s [[Cheremosh Ukrainian Dance Company|Cheremosh]] and [[Ukrainian Shumka Dancers|Shumka]] troupes – among the world's elite [[Ukrainian dance|Ukrainian dancers]]; or the [[Ukrainian Cultural Heritage Village]] – a living-history museum approximately 39 kilometres east of Edmonton where Ukrainian [[Post-Confederation Canada (1867–1914)#Immigration to the West|pioneer buildings]] are displayed along with extensive cultural exhibits.
+
+Ukrainian Canadians have also contributed to [[Culture of Canada|Canadian culture]] as a whole. Actress and comedian [[Luba Goy]], singer [[Gloria Kaye]],<ref>Czuboka, p. 211-212.</ref> ''[[Jeopardy!]]'' host [[Alex Trebek]], hockey executive [[Kyle Dubas]], and painter [[William Kurelek]], for example, are well known outside the Ukrainian community.
+
+Perhaps one of the most lasting contributions Ukrainian Canadians have made to the wider culture of Canada is the concept of [[multiculturalism]],<ref name="SwyripaLambertEncyc">{{Cite web |last1=Swyripa |first1=Frances A |last2=Lambert |first2=Maude-Emmanuelle |date=December 10, 2021 |title=Ukrainian Canadians |url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ukrainian-canadians |access-date=2 April 2022 |website=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |publisher=[[Historica Canada]]}}</ref><ref name="Cuenco2021">{{Cite journal |last=Cuenco |first=Michael |date=Spring 2021 |title=A Tale of Two Immigration Systems: Canada and the United States |url=https://americanaffairsjournal.org/2021/02/a-tale-of-two-immigration-systems-canada-and-the-united-states/ |journal=[[American Affairs]] |publisher=American Affairs Foundation Inc |volume=V |issue=1}}</ref> which was promoted as early as 1963 by [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] [[Paul Yuzyk]].<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> During and after the debates surrounding the [[Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism]], Ukrainian leaders, such as linguist [[Jaroslav Rudnyckyj]], came out in force against the idea of [[Constitutional debate in Canada|English – French]] [[biculturalism]],<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> which they believed denied the contributions other peoples had made to Canada. Partly in response to this, Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]] shifted Canada to a policy of official multiculturalism; notably, the day after the [[Canadian Multiculturalism Policy of 1971]] was officially announced, Trudeau gave a forceful speech in support of the policy at a national assembly of the [[Ukrainian Canadian Congress]] in Winnipeg.<ref name="Cuenco2021" />
+
+== U.S. ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Americans}}
+{{Expand section|date=June 2024}}
+According to U.S. census estimates, in 2021 there were 1,017,586 Americans of Ukrainian descent representing 0.3% of the American population.  The Ukrainian population of the United States is thus the second largest outside the former [[Eastern Bloc]]; only [[Canada]] has a larger [[Ukrainian Canadians|Ukrainian community]] under this definition.
+
+== Brazil ==
+{{Main articles|Ukrainian Brazilians}}
+[[File:Casa_típica_de_imigrantes_da_Ucrânia_no_Brasil_Medium_Size.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian village architecture in [[Curitiba]].]]
+[[File:Memorial_Ucraniano_-_Curitiba.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian church in Tingüi Park, [[Curitiba]].]]
+[[File:Solenidades._Homenagens_(27678560363).jpg|right|thumb|Solemnity for Ukrainians in the [[Senate of Brazil]], in [[Brasília]].]]
+[[File:Entrada_da_Igreja_do_Arcanjo_Miguel.jpg|right|thumb|Entrance to the Ukrainian Church in [[Mallet, Paraná|Mallet]].]]
+Although most Brazilian Ukrainians have lived in Brazil for 4-5 generations and few have ever seen Ukraine,<ref name="rivne">[http://www.rivnepost.rv.ua/showarticle.php?art=018403 ''Rivne Vechirne''] (Evening Rivne). 2003. Issue No. 41 (Ukrainian). Article written by Dmytro Yatsuk.</ref> they have preserved their [[Ukrainian language|language]] and culture to a large degree in rural Paraná state.<ref name="Boruszenko">Oksana Boruszenko and Rev. Danyil Kozlinsky (1994). ''Ukrainians in Brazil'' (Chapter), in ''Ukraine and Ukrainians Throughout the World'', edited by Ann Lencyk Pawliczko, University of Toronto Press: Toronto, pp. 443-454</ref> This has largely been due to the colossal efforts of the Ukrainian Churches.<ref name="rivne" /> In contrast, among the [[Ukrainian Argentine|Ukrainians in Argentina]] where the Church was not as strong as in Brazil, the Ukrainian language has largely disappeared.<ref name="den">{{cite news |last=Gudzyk |first=Klara |date=August 23, 2002 |script-title=uk:П'яте покоління: Українці Бразилії зберігають свої традиції |trans-title=Fifth generation: Ukrainians of Brazil preserve their traditions |url=https://day.kyiv.ua/uk/article/cuspilstvo/pyate-pokolinnya |access-date=January 7, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Day (Kiev)|The Day]] |language=uk}}</ref>
+
+Among those who live in the colonies, or agricultural settlements, Ukrainian is widely spoken at home, in church, and in the community, and today it is not uncommon for Ukrainian children to be unable to speak the Portuguese language until they begin school. Despite the Ukrainian language's widespread use in everyday speech, the ability to read and write is more limited, with over 50% of the Ukrainian population being unable to write in the Ukrainian language.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20191218192140/http://rius.kiev.ua/Diaspora/boru ''Brazilian Ukraine and Globalization.''] Borushenko, O.P. Professor, Federal University of Paraná. Text of his presentation "Diaspora as a Leader in Support for the Ukrainian State in International Relations. June 18–20, 2008.</ref>
+
+Due to isolation from Ukraine, the Ukrainians of Brazil speak a 100-year-old form of the language's [[Ukrainian dialects|Galician or "Upper Dniestrian" dialect]].<ref name="rivne" /> Ninety percent of Church services are conducted in the Ukrainian language (in contrast, among the 700,000 [[Polish Brazilian|ethnic Poles in Brazil]] only two churches use the Polish language).<ref name="den" />
+
+The Portuguese language has only come into wide use in the youngest generation - those who are younger than fifteen years old.<ref name="rivne" /> Paraná boasts five [[Ukrainian-language]] radio stations,<ref name="den" /> including "Zabava" which broadcasts news, Ukrainian folk and pop music, and the [[Divine Liturgy]].<ref name="rivne" /> In addition, Brazil has 23 Ukrainian dance troupes.<ref name="CIUS">Press Release. [https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf Scholars Impressed with Ukrainian Life in Brazil.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515191940/http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf|date=May 15, 2013}} Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta. 2009</ref> In the rural areas, Ukrainians rarely marry non-Ukrainians, and mixed marriages generally adopt the Ukrainian culture.<ref name="Boruszenko" />
+
+The Ukrainians' neighbors - [[Caboclo|Caboclos]], Poles, Germans, Italians, and some Dutch - at times accuse the Ukrainians and their priests of maintaining an exclusiveness that sometimes borders on racism, although non-Brazilians who visit the local Ukrainians are treated with the utmost civility.<ref name="pitravel">[http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html Pacific Island Travel web-site, accessed 4.8.08] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903043907/http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html|date=September 3, 2008}}, taken from: ''Brazil: the Rough Guide'', by David Cleary, Dilwyn Jenkins, Oliver Marshall, Jim Hine. {{ISBN|1-85828-223-3}}</ref> Ukrainians in Brazil commonly refer to themselves and to Ukrainians from other countries as "our people" (''Nashi Liudy'') and to non-Ukrainians of any nationality as "blacks" (''Chorni'').<ref name="rivne" />
+
+The situation in urban areas is quite different. In the cities, Ukrainians tend to become assimilated into Brazilian culture<ref name="Boruszenko" /> and to adopt the [[Portuguese language]].<ref name="rivne" />
+
 === Music ===
 Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.

 Traditional peasant folk art, embroidery and vernacular architecture are critical to Ukrainian culture, and its elements have often been determined by the resources available at the time. The country's strong tradition of folk art and embroidery continues to this day, with [[Ukrainian embroidery]] often considered an art form in itself.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}

-Prior to the [[Soviet Union]], the Ukrainian culture has had heavy influence from other East Slavic cultures such as [[Culture of Russia|Russian]] and [[Belarusian culture]].<ref name="Conv_RusUk">{{cite web |title=How Russian is Ukraine? |url=https://theconversation.com/how-russian-is-ukraine-clue-not-as-much-as-vladimir-putin-insists-173758 |website=The Conversation |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

 Ukrainian culture has had to overcome numerous obstacles in order to survive and retain its originality, since foreign powers and empires who dominated the country and its people in the past often implemented policies aimed at assimilating the Ukrainian population into their own population, as well as trying to eradicate and purge elements of the culture. @@ -40,7 +40,7 @@
 ===Holidays and celebrations ===
 [[File:Shepherds Bow - Google Art Project.jpg|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] icon, [[Adoration of the Shepherds]], from the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]] collection. Artist unknown, c. 1670.]]
 [[File:Фестиваль «Спалах Різдвяної звізди 2017".jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in [[Lviv]] celebrate Christmas with traditional [[Koliada]] festival "The flash of Christmas star".]] 
-{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Kupala Night|Ivan Kupala Night]], [[Maslenitsa|Masliana]] (Masnytsia), [[Koledari|Koliaduvannia]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups.<ref name="IE_Razom">{{cite web |title=Ukraine's fight for a democratic future |url=https://isiseurope.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/the-russian-way-or-the-highway-ukraines-fight-for-a-democratic-future/ |website=Isis Europe |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>
+{{See also|Public holidays in Ukraine}}Social gatherings like [[Vechornytsi]] have a long history in Ukrainian culture, and so do traditional [[Public holidays in Ukraine|holidays]] like [[Kupala Night|Ivan Kupala Night]], [[Maslenitsa|Masliana]] (Masnytsia), [[Koledari|Koliaduvannia]], and [[Malanka]], where people gather in large groups.<ref name="IE_Razom">{{cite web |title=Ukraine's fight for a democratic future |url=https://isiseurope.wordpress.com/2014/01/28/the-russian-way-or-the-highway-ukraines-fight-for-a-democratic-future/ |website=Isis Europe |date=28 January 2014 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>

@@ -64,7 +64,7 @@
 ===Ornamental and visual art===
 [[File:Hnizdovsky Rizdvo2.gif|thumbnail|[[Christmas in Ukraine|Christmas]] card by [[Jacques Hnizdovsky]]]]
 
-On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in Ukrainian painting ([[Petrykivka painting|Petrykivka]], [[Kosiv painted ceramics|Kosiv]], Opishnia, Bubnivka), ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Historical regions in present-day Ukraine|Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed in [[UNESCO]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://ich.unesco.org/en/state/ukraine-UA |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220706095944/https://ich.unesco.org/en/state/ukraine-UA |archive-date=2022-07-06 |access-date=2023-10-05 |website=UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage}}</ref> and National<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про затвердження Порядку ведення Національного переліку елементів нематеріальної культурної спадщини України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/z0020-18 |accessdate=2023-02-01 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-20 |title=Національний перелік елементів нематеріальної культурної спадщини України |url=https://mcip.gov.ua/kulturna-spadshchyna/natsionalnyy-perelik-elementiv-nematerialnoi-kulturnoi-spadshchyny-ukrainy/ |access-date=2023-11-22 |website=mcip.gov.ua |language=uk}}</ref> lists of [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]].
+On special occasions, every aspect of ordinary life is transformed into ornamental art form of artistic expression. Ornamentation and design motifs are steeped in symbolism, religious [[ritual]] and meaning.<ref name="EoU_Orn">{{cite web |title=Ornament |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CO%5CR%5COrnament.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> From the [[illuminated manuscripts]] of the [[Peresopnytsia Gospel]]<ref name="EoU_Gospel">{{cite web |title=Peresopnytsia Gospel |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CP%5CE%5CPeresopnytsiaGospel.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> to the famous [[Pysanka|pysanky]] and [[Vytynanky (Wycinanki)|vytynanky]], intricate details have ancient meaning. Much of the oral history was lost during the past 300 years of [[Russification of Ukraine]] when Ukrainian culture and language were forbidden.<ref>{{cite web |title=Executed Renaissance: The Erasure of Ukrainian Cultural Heritage in the Times of the Soviet Union |url=https://retrospectjournal.com/2020/11/22/executed-renaissance-the-erasure-of-ukrainian-cultural-heritage-in-the-times-of-the-soviet-union/ |website=Retrospect Journal |date=22 November 2020 |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> Organizations like the [[Ivan Honchar Museum]], [[Pysanka Museum]] and the [[Ukrainian Museum]] are dedicated to historic preservation. Different regions of Ukraine have their own traditional ornamentation with their own variation of style and meaning. Examples can be seen in Ukrainian painting ([[Petrykivka painting|Petrykivka]], [[Kosiv painted ceramics|Kosiv]], Opishnia, Bubnivka), ornamental architecture, [[Ukrainian embroidery]], and textile motifs from various [[Historical regions in present-day Ukraine|Ukrainian historical regions]]. Some of these works are inscribed in [[UNESCO]]<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://ich.unesco.org/en/state/ukraine-UA |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220706095944/https://ich.unesco.org/en/state/ukraine-UA |archive-date=2022-07-06 |access-date=2023-10-05 |website=UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage}}</ref> and National<ref>{{Cite web |title=Про затвердження Порядку ведення Національного переліку елементів нематеріальної культурної спадщини України |url=https://zakon.rada.gov.ua/go/z0020-18 |accessdate=2023-02-01 |website=Офіційний вебпортал парламенту України |language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-20 |title=Національний перелік елементів нематеріальної культурної спадщини України |url=https://mcip.gov.ua/kulturna-spadshchyna/natsionalnyy-perelik-elementiv-nematerialnoi-kulturnoi-spadshchyny-ukrainy/ |access-date=2023-11-22 |website=mcip.gov.ua |language=uk}}</ref> lists of [[Intangible Cultural Heritage of Ukraine]].
 
 ====Jewelry====
 {{Main|History of jewellery in Ukraine}}
@@ -75,7 +75,7 @@
 ====Traditional costume====
 [[File:Carpatho-Rusyn sub-groups - Transcarpathian Rusyns in original goral folk-costumes from Maramureş ..jpg|thumb|Ukrainians in national dress]]
 {{Main|Ukrainian national clothing}}
-The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |publisher=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
+The iconic embroidered shirt or blouse, the [[vyshyvanka]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Ukrainian Vyshyvanka (embroidered shirt) |date=17 January 2012 |url=http://unknownukraine.com/ukrainian-vyshyvanka/ |publisher=Unknown Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> is the most recognizable part of Ukrainian national costume, and even has its own public celebration in May.<ref name="Unian_Vysh">{{cite web |title=Ukrainians celebrating Vyshyvanka Day on May 20 |url=https://www.unian.info/society/vyshyvanka-day-ukrainians-worldwide-praise-one-of-national-symbols-on-may-20-11426332.html |website=Unian |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> For men, traditional dress also includes [[kozhukh]], [[kontusz]], [[żupan]] and [[sharovary]]. For women, traditional dress includes [[kozhushanka]], [[ochipok]] for married women, and [[Ukrainian wreath]] for unmarried girls. Garments are made using elaborate structural design, complicated weaving techniques, extensive embroidery, and [[Cutwork|cutwork needlework]].{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}

initial_version: The country of Ukraine consists of a varying compilation of ethnic groups.  Ukrainians make up nearly 75% of the population, with Russians compiling 22% of the overall population.  The rest of the population is a collection of varying peoples.  The remaining minority groups are Polish, Belarussian, Moldovan, and Hungarian.  Religion is also practiced thought the country, Christianity and Catholicism are the two largely practiced religions.  The Ukrainian Orthodox Church is the largest church in the country. The other church is the Ukrainian Catholic Church which is united with the Roman Catholic Church.  As well as having churches, Ukraine also has seven universities throughout the country.
changed_version:
--- 
+++ 
@@ -137,39 +137,6 @@
 
 Today in use there are two types of alphabet: Cyrillic and Latin. Initially Crimean Tatars used Arabic script. In 1928 it was replaced with the Latin alphabet. Cyrillic was introduced in 1938 based on the Russian alphabet. The Cyrillic alphabet was the only official one between 1938 and 1997. All its letters coincide with those of the Russian alphabet. The 1990s saw the start of the gradual transition of the language to the new Latin alphabet based on the Turkish one.<ref>{{Cite web |date=21 March 2017 |title=Crimean Tatars: A to Z |url=https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220223100710/https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |archive-date=23 February 2022 |access-date=23 February 2022}}</ref>
 
-== Canada ==
-{{Main articles|Ukrainian Canadians}}
-First Ukrainians have arrived in Canada in 1891, bringing their Ukrainian traditions with them, which they preserved and propagated, enriching their new home with it, and maintaining their separate ethnicity.<ref>{{Cite thesis |title=Ukrainian cultural traditions in Canada: Theatre, choral music and dance, 1891-1967. |url=http://hdl.handle.net/10393/10564 |publisher=University of Ottawa (Canada) |date=1977 |language=en |first=Alexandra |last=Pritz}}</ref>
-
-Having been separated from Ukraine, Ukrainian Canadians have developed their own distinctive Ukrainian culture in Canada. To showcase their unique hybrid culture, Ukrainian Canadians have created institutions that showcase Ukrainian Canadian culture such as [[Edmonton]]'s [[Cheremosh Ukrainian Dance Company|Cheremosh]] and [[Ukrainian Shumka Dancers|Shumka]] troupes – among the world's elite [[Ukrainian dance|Ukrainian dancers]]; or the [[Ukrainian Cultural Heritage Village]] – a living-history museum approximately 39 kilometres east of Edmonton where Ukrainian [[Post-Confederation Canada (1867–1914)#Immigration to the West|pioneer buildings]] are displayed along with extensive cultural exhibits.
-
-Ukrainian Canadians have also contributed to [[Culture of Canada|Canadian culture]] as a whole. Actress and comedian [[Luba Goy]], singer [[Gloria Kaye]],<ref>Czuboka, p. 211-212.</ref> ''[[Jeopardy!]]'' host [[Alex Trebek]], hockey executive [[Kyle Dubas]], and painter [[William Kurelek]], for example, are well known outside the Ukrainian community.
-
-Perhaps one of the most lasting contributions Ukrainian Canadians have made to the wider culture of Canada is the concept of [[multiculturalism]],<ref name="SwyripaLambertEncyc">{{Cite web |last1=Swyripa |first1=Frances A |last2=Lambert |first2=Maude-Emmanuelle |date=December 10, 2021 |title=Ukrainian Canadians |url=https://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/ukrainian-canadians |access-date=2 April 2022 |website=[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]] |publisher=[[Historica Canada]]}}</ref><ref name="Cuenco2021">{{Cite journal |last=Cuenco |first=Michael |date=Spring 2021 |title=A Tale of Two Immigration Systems: Canada and the United States |url=https://americanaffairsjournal.org/2021/02/a-tale-of-two-immigration-systems-canada-and-the-united-states/ |journal=[[American Affairs]] |publisher=American Affairs Foundation Inc |volume=V |issue=1}}</ref> which was promoted as early as 1963 by [[Senate of Canada|Senator]] [[Paul Yuzyk]].<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> During and after the debates surrounding the [[Royal Commission on Bilingualism and Biculturalism]], Ukrainian leaders, such as linguist [[Jaroslav Rudnyckyj]], came out in force against the idea of [[Constitutional debate in Canada|English – French]] [[biculturalism]],<ref name="Cuenco2021" /> which they believed denied the contributions other peoples had made to Canada. Partly in response to this, Prime Minister [[Pierre Trudeau]] shifted Canada to a policy of official multiculturalism; notably, the day after the [[Canadian Multiculturalism Policy of 1971]] was officially announced, Trudeau gave a forceful speech in support of the policy at a national assembly of the [[Ukrainian Canadian Congress]] in Winnipeg.<ref name="Cuenco2021" />
-
-== U.S. ==
-{{Main articles|Ukrainian Americans}}
-{{Expand section|date=June 2024}}
-According to U.S. census estimates, in 2021 there were 1,017,586 Americans of Ukrainian descent representing 0.3% of the American population.  The Ukrainian population of the United States is thus the second largest outside the former [[Eastern Bloc]]; only [[Canada]] has a larger [[Ukrainian Canadians|Ukrainian community]] under this definition.
-
-== Brazil ==
-{{Main articles|Ukrainian Brazilians}}
-[[File:Casa_típica_de_imigrantes_da_Ucrânia_no_Brasil_Medium_Size.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian village architecture in [[Curitiba]].]]
-[[File:Memorial_Ucraniano_-_Curitiba.jpg|thumb|Ukrainian church in Tingüi Park, [[Curitiba]].]]
-[[File:Solenidades._Homenagens_(27678560363).jpg|right|thumb|Solemnity for Ukrainians in the [[Senate of Brazil]], in [[Brasília]].]]
-[[File:Entrada_da_Igreja_do_Arcanjo_Miguel.jpg|right|thumb|Entrance to the Ukrainian Church in [[Mallet, Paraná|Mallet]].]]
-Although most Brazilian Ukrainians have lived in Brazil for 4-5 generations and few have ever seen Ukraine,<ref name="rivne">[http://www.rivnepost.rv.ua/showarticle.php?art=018403 ''Rivne Vechirne''] (Evening Rivne). 2003. Issue No. 41 (Ukrainian). Article written by Dmytro Yatsuk.</ref> they have preserved their [[Ukrainian language|language]] and culture to a large degree in rural Paraná state.<ref name="Boruszenko">Oksana Boruszenko and Rev. Danyil Kozlinsky (1994). ''Ukrainians in Brazil'' (Chapter), in ''Ukraine and Ukrainians Throughout the World'', edited by Ann Lencyk Pawliczko, University of Toronto Press: Toronto, pp. 443-454</ref> This has largely been due to the colossal efforts of the Ukrainian Churches.<ref name="rivne" /> In contrast, among the [[Ukrainian Argentine|Ukrainians in Argentina]] where the Church was not as strong as in Brazil, the Ukrainian language has largely disappeared.<ref name="den">{{cite news |last=Gudzyk |first=Klara |date=August 23, 2002 |script-title=uk:П'яте покоління: Українці Бразилії зберігають свої традиції |trans-title=Fifth generation: Ukrainians of Brazil preserve their traditions |url=https://day.kyiv.ua/uk/article/cuspilstvo/pyate-pokolinnya |access-date=January 7, 2017 |newspaper=[[The Day (Kiev)|The Day]] |language=uk}}</ref>
-
-Among those who live in the colonies, or agricultural settlements, Ukrainian is widely spoken at home, in church, and in the community, and today it is not uncommon for Ukrainian children to be unable to speak the Portuguese language until they begin school. Despite the Ukrainian language's widespread use in everyday speech, the ability to read and write is more limited, with over 50% of the Ukrainian population being unable to write in the Ukrainian language.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20191218192140/http://rius.kiev.ua/Diaspora/boru ''Brazilian Ukraine and Globalization.''] Borushenko, O.P. Professor, Federal University of Paraná. Text of his presentation "Diaspora as a Leader in Support for the Ukrainian State in International Relations. June 18–20, 2008.</ref>
-
-Due to isolation from Ukraine, the Ukrainians of Brazil speak a 100-year-old form of the language's [[Ukrainian dialects|Galician or "Upper Dniestrian" dialect]].<ref name="rivne" /> Ninety percent of Church services are conducted in the Ukrainian language (in contrast, among the 700,000 [[Polish Brazilian|ethnic Poles in Brazil]] only two churches use the Polish language).<ref name="den" />
-
-The Portuguese language has only come into wide use in the youngest generation - those who are younger than fifteen years old.<ref name="rivne" /> Paraná boasts five [[Ukrainian-language]] radio stations,<ref name="den" /> including "Zabava" which broadcasts news, Ukrainian folk and pop music, and the [[Divine Liturgy]].<ref name="rivne" /> In addition, Brazil has 23 Ukrainian dance troupes.<ref name="CIUS">Press Release. [https://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf Scholars Impressed with Ukrainian Life in Brazil.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515191940/http://www.ualberta.ca/CIUS/announce/media/Media%202009/2009-06-29_Ukrainian%20Life%20in%20Brazil%20(eng).pdf|date=May 15, 2013}} Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, University of Alberta. 2009</ref> In the rural areas, Ukrainians rarely marry non-Ukrainians, and mixed marriages generally adopt the Ukrainian culture.<ref name="Boruszenko" />
-
-The Ukrainians' neighbors - [[Caboclo|Caboclos]], Poles, Germans, Italians, and some Dutch - at times accuse the Ukrainians and their priests of maintaining an exclusiveness that sometimes borders on racism, although non-Brazilians who visit the local Ukrainians are treated with the utmost civility.<ref name="pitravel">[http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html Pacific Island Travel web-site, accessed 4.8.08] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080903043907/http://www.pacificislandtravel.com/south_america/brazil/about_destin/southcentralparana.html|date=September 3, 2008}}, taken from: ''Brazil: the Rough Guide'', by David Cleary, Dilwyn Jenkins, Oliver Marshall, Jim Hine. {{ISBN|1-85828-223-3}}</ref> Ukrainians in Brazil commonly refer to themselves and to Ukrainians from other countries as "our people" (''Nashi Liudy'') and to non-Ukrainians of any nationality as "blacks" (''Chorni'').<ref name="rivne" />
-
-The situation in urban areas is quite different. In the cities, Ukrainians tend to become assimilated into Brazilian culture<ref name="Boruszenko" /> and to adopt the [[Portuguese language]].<ref name="rivne" />
-
 === Music ===
 Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.

@@ -17,7 +17,7 @@
 
 ==History==
 [[File:Pektoral111.JPG|thumb|Gold Pectoral from [[Tovsta Mohyla]]|alt=Gold ornament of the Scythian era discovered at Tovsta Mohyla]]
-[[File: Basilica interior of St. Sophia Cathedral 03.jpg|thumb|Interior of [[Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in Kyiv]] 
+[[File:Оранта Софії Київської.jpg|thumb|Interior of [[Saint Sophia Cathedral, Kyiv|Saint Sophia Cathedral]] in Kyiv]]
 Although the country has often struggled to preserve its independence<ref name="Brit_Ukraine">{{cite web |title=Ukraine |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Ukraine |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> its people have managed to retain their cultural possessions and are proud of the considerable cultural legacy they have created. Numerous writers have contributed to the country's literary history such as [[Ivan Kotliarevsky]], [[Taras Shevchenko]]<ref name="EoU_Shevchenko">{{cite web |title=Shevchenko, Taras |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108142329/http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CS%5CH%5CShevchenkoTaras.htm |archive-date=8 January 2018 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and [[Ivan Franko]].<ref name="EoU_Franko">{{cite web |title=Franko, Ivan |url=http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/pages/F/R/FrankoIvan.htm |website=Encyclopedia of Ukraine |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref> The Ukrainian culture has experienced a significant resurgence<ref name="Brit_KyivanRus">{{cite web |title=Kyivan Rus |url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Kyivan-Rus |website=Britannica |access-date=7 March 2022}}</ref>{{failed verification|date=August 2022}} since the establishment of independence in 1991.{{Citation needed|date=August 2022}}
 
 The earliest evidence of [[Cultural artifact|cultural artefacts]] in the Ukrainian lands can be traced to decorated [[mammoth]] tusks in the Neanderthal era.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=24}} Later, the [[Nomad|nomadic tribes]] of the southern lands of the 4th century BCE, like the [[Scythians]], produced finely worked gold ornaments such as the pectoral found in the [[Tovsta Mohyla]] mound.{{sfn|Kurkov|2022|p=25}}

 == Crimean Tatars ==
-[[Crimean Tatars]] are the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] of the [[Crimea]].
+{{see also|Crimean Tatar language|Crimean Tatar literature}}[[Crimean Tatars]] are the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous people]] of the [[Crimea]].
+[[File:Crimean_tatar_musician.jpg|thumb|Crimean Tatar musician]]
+[[Yurts]] or nomadic tents have traditionally played an important role in the cultural history of Crimean Tatars. There are different types of yurts; some are large and collapsible, called "terme", while others are small and non-collapsible (otav).
+
+On the [[Nowruz]] holiday, Crimean Tatars usually cook eggs, chicken soup, puff meat pie (kobete), [[halva]], and sweet biscuits. Children put on masks and sing special songs under the windows of their neighbours, receiving sweets in return.
+
+The songs (makam) of the nomadic steppe Crimean Tatars are characterized by diatonic, melodic simplicity and brevity. The songs of mountainous and southern coastal Crimean Tatars, called {{lang|crh-Latn|Türkü}}, are sung with richly ornamented melodies. Household [[lyricism]] is also widespread. Occasionally, song competitions take place between young men and women during Crimean holidays and weddings. Ritual [[folklore]] includes winter greetings, wedding songs, lamentations and circular dance songs (khoran). Epic stories or destans are very popular among the Crimean Tatars, particularly the destans of "Chora batyr", "Edige", "[[Koroghlu|Koroglu]]" and others.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Gertsen |first1=A |title=Crimean Tatars |url=https://bigenc.ru/ethnology/text/5685404 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210308012134/https://bigenc.ru/ethnology/text/5685404 |archive-date=8 March 2021 |access-date=12 July 2021 |website=Big Russian Encyclopedia |publisher=Ministry of Culture of the Russian Federation |language=Russian}}</ref>
+
+Today in use there are two types of alphabet: Cyrillic and Latin. Initially Crimean Tatars used Arabic script. In 1928 it was replaced with the Latin alphabet. Cyrillic was introduced in 1938 based on the Russian alphabet. The Cyrillic alphabet was the only official one between 1938 and 1997. All its letters coincide with those of the Russian alphabet. The 1990s saw the start of the gradual transition of the language to the new Latin alphabet based on the Turkish one.<ref>{{Cite web |date=21 March 2017 |title=Crimean Tatars: A to Z |url=https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220223100710/https://uacrisis.org/en/53926-les-tatars-de-crimee-de-z |archive-date=23 February 2022 |access-date=23 February 2022}}</ref>
 
 === Music ===
 Modern Crimean Tatar and [[Armenians|Armenian]] origins signer, [[Jamala]], won the [[Eurovision Song Contest|Eurovision]] contest in 2016. She sings [[jazz]], soul, funk, folk, pop and electro, and is also the author of most of her songs<ref>{{Cite web |title=Modern culture of the Crimean Tatars |url=https://ukraine.ua/stories/modern-culture-of-the-crimean-tatars/ |website=Official website of Ukraine}}</ref>.
